{"comments": {"id": 182, "count": 81, "talk_id": 201}, "threadId": 182, "requested_language_english_name": "English", "current_talk": "201", "description": "Lakshmi Pratury remembers the lost art of letter-writing and shares a series of notes her father wrote to her before he died. Her short but heartfelt talk may inspire you to set pen to paper, too.", "event": "TED2007", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "Lakshmi Pratury: The lost art of letter-writing", "slug": "lakshmi_pratury_on_letter_writing", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "179", "slug": "lakshmi_pratury", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Lakshmi", "lastname": "Pratury", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Connector", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/22828_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "Q: What should a multicultural woman do to grow as a leader?\r\nA: I have always felt being a woman is an asset, being brown is an asset, having an accent is an asset. The thing that is most intrinsic to multicultural women is that they have great cultural sensitivities. Be comfortable with who you are and understand that you have an edge.", "whotheyare": "Lakshmi Pratury is the host of The INK Conference and was the co-host of TEDIndia 2009.", "whylisten": "

After two decades in marketing, venture capitalism and social entreprenuership, Lakshmi Pratury turned her focus toward linking her home country of India more tightly with the American community. Her firm, Ixoraa Media, runs meetings and events to spark dialogue and make connections. In 2009, she co-hosted TEDIndia and saw such a warm response to the conference that she founded The INK Conference, in partnership with TED, that would pick up where TEDIndia left off. Watch the INKTalks channel  to see some of the brilliant ideas shared at the INK Conference. Pratury blogs at Lakshmi's Lounge.

She worked at Intel for 12 years as a marketer and evangelist, then moved to a VC firm, Global Capitalist Partners. At GCP, she focused on connecting India's legendary software-development community with US tech. She began to focus more strictly on relationship-building with her move to the America India Foundation, where she founded the AIF's Digital Equalizer program, offering technology education to some 80,000 children and 2,000 teachers in India. She also launched the AIF Summit for social entrepreneurs from India.

"whatotherssay": "Q: What should a multicultural woman do to grow as a leader?\r\nA: I have always felt being a woman is an asset, being brown is an asset, having an accent is an asset. The thing that is most intrinsic to multicultural women is that they have great cultural sensitivities. Be comfortable with who you are and understand that you have an edge.", "whotheyare": "Lakshmi Pratury is the host of The INK Conference and was the co-host of TEDIndia 2009.", "whylisten": "

After two decades in marketing, venture capitalism and social entreprenuership, Lakshmi Pratury turned her focus toward linking her home country of India more tightly with the American community. Her firm, Ixoraa Media, runs meetings and events to spark dialogue and make connections. In 2009, she co-hosted TEDIndia and saw such a warm response to the conference that she founded The INK Conference, in partnership with TED, that would pick up where TEDIndia left off. Watch the INKTalks channel  to see some of the brilliant ideas shared at the INK Conference. Pratury blogs at Lakshmi's Lounge.

She worked at Intel for 12 years as a marketer and evangelist, then moved to a VC firm, Global Capitalist Partners. At GCP, she focused on connecting India's legendary software-development community with US tech. She began to focus more strictly on relationship-building with her move to the America India Foundation, where she founded the AIF's Digital Equalizer program, offering technology education to some 80,000 children and 2,000 teachers in India. She also launched the AIF Summit for social entrepreneurs from India.

author: Lakshmi_Pratury;
title: The lost art of letter-writing

aws-transcripts.transcript: so I thought I would talk about death. Seemed to be the passion today. Actually, it's not about death. It's inevitable, terrible. But really, what I want to talk about is I'm just fascinated by the legacy people leave when they die. That's what I want to talk about. So Art Buchwald left his legacy of humor with a video that appeared soon after he died, saying, Hi, I'm Art Buchwald and I just Died and Mike, who I met at Galapagos Trip, which they wanna Ted, is leaving notes on cyberspace, where his chronicling chronicling his journey through cancer and my father left me a legacy of his handwriting through letters and a notebook in the last two years of his life. When you're sick, he filled a notebook with his thoughts about me. He told about my strengths, weaknesses and gentle suggestions for improvement, according according specific incidents, and held a mirror to my life. After he died, I realized that no one writes to me anymore. Handwriting is a disappearing art. I'm all for email in thinking while typing. But why give up old habits for new? Why can't we have letter writing an email exchange in our lives. There are times when I want to trade. All those years that I was too busy to sit with my dad and chat with him and treat all those years for one hug but too late. But that's when I take out his letters and I read them and the paper that touched his hand is in mine, and I feel connected to him. So maybe we all need to leave our children with the value legacy and not a financial one. A value for things with the personal touch. An autograph book, a soul searching letter. If a fraction of this powerful Ted audience could be inspired to buy a beautiful paper John, it'll be recycled one and write a beautiful letter to someone they love. We actually may start a revolution where our children may go to penmanship classes. So what do I plan to leave for my son? I collect autograph books, and those of you authors in the audience know I hound you for them and CDs to a Tracy. I plan to publish my own notebook as I witnessed my father's body being swallowed by fire. I sat by his funeral pyre and wrote. I have no idea how I'm gonna do it, but I am committed to compiling his thoughts and mine into a book and leave that published book for my son. I'd like to end with a few verses of what I wrote at my father's cremation. And those linguists please pardon the grammar because I've not looked at it in the last 10 years. I took it out for the first time to come here. Picture in a frame, ashes in a bottle, boundless energy confined in the bottle, forcing me to deal with reality, forcing me to deal with being grown up. I hear you, and I know that you would want me to be strong, but right now I'm being sucked down, surrounded and suffocated by these raging emotional waters, craving to cleanse my soul, trying to emerge on a farm footing one more time to keep on fighting and flourishing. Just as you taught me, you're encouraging whispers in my role pool of despair, holding me and heaving me two shores of sanity to live again and to love again. Thank you
